GOP options becoming more limited in Senate race

Three high-profile Republicans said Monday they will not run in the special US Senate election, which could force the party to back an unknown candidate. (Globe)
  • Discuss Who should run on the GOP ticket?
  • 2/4 Healey, Weld, Romney, won't run for Senate seat

Transgender woman settles suit with city

The City of Boston has agreed to pay Brenda Wernikoff (pictured) $20,000 in exchange for dropping her suit against the officers who arrested her in 2010. The department is also reviewing how it interacts with the transgender community. (Globe)
  • Discuss What do you think of the settlement?
  • 1/18 DOC chief ordered to prep for inmate's sex-change
  • 1/17 Mass. groups hold transgender awareness day
  • 7/1/2012 Mass. Transgender Rights Act Becomes Law

Is South Boston’s new reality show real?

A&E's "Southie Rules" was billed as a drama about a local family facing neighborhood gentrification. In reality, the show is more of an unscripted sitcom. (Globe)

Kimmel takes earlier time slot in stride

After spending a decade in the midnight hour on ABC, “Jimmy Kimmel Live!” moved up to the 11:35 p.m. slot and saw higher ratings. (Globe)

Rep. Lynch changes tone on abortion rights

Representative Stephen Lynch, who has consistently described himself as an antiabortion legislator, said he believes abortion should be legal but rare.
Opinion | Kevin Cullen

Representatives Ed Markey and Stephen Lynch, the two Democrats who want to replace John Kerry in the US Senate, come from very similar places.

Bridge lacked height warning

On Saturday, a bus ferrying high school students slammed into the Western Avenue bridge, at a spot that was once slated to get a rubber warning sign but never did.
Opinion | Farah Stockman

Was the financial crisis caused by the unrealistic thought that bad things won’t happen?

Yes, media violence is the diversionary tactic of choice for the NRA, but TV violence is actually a bipartisan complaint.
